home-text-1: I'm a full stack developer specializing in geotechnologies. I have extensive experience with major frontend development tools like React, Angular, TypeScript, and Next.js. I'm also proficient in map libraries such as Mapbox, OpenLayers, Cesium, Three.JS, Potree, and GeoServer, and have worked with a variety of backend frameworks including Django, Express.js, and Nest.js.
home-text-2: I graduated with a degree in Surveying and Cartographic Engineering in Universidade Federal de Viçosa, hold a Master's degree in Civil Engineering with a focus on Spatial Information, and I'm currently pursuing a Ph.D. in Civil Engineering, also focusing on Spatial Information.
home-text-3: I founded and run my own software house, where I initially served as CEO before transitioning to consulting and technical leadership. I now focus on technical development and innovative projects, and I'm open to consulting opportunities both in Brazil and abroad.
project-dragonfly-description: Dragonfly is a geointelligence platform focused on combating arboviruses endemic to Brazil, such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya.
project-geoportal-itabirito-description: The Geoportal Itabirito is an innovative platform that consolidates data from the Multipurpose Territorial Cadastre of the municipality of Itabirito.
project-dragonfly-intro: In popular culture, dragonflies are known for preying on mosquito larvae that transmit arboviruses. Inspired by this concept, Dragonfly GeoAnalytics is a platform developed to help municipalities combat arboviruses by mapping outbreak sites and disease cases through aerial images captured by drones. This allows for real-time monitoring of statistics and analysis on the progression of these diseases.
project-dragonfly-dev: Dragonfly was developed as an ecosystem: it features a React frontend, two backends—one for data provision using Express.js and another for OAuth authentication using Django REST Framework—along with additional components like a pg_tileserv server and a PostGIS database to provide tiles in MVT format.
project-dragonfly-frontend: On the frontend, I utilized the react-map-gl library for rendering maps with Mapbox and the Highcharts library for chart rendering. UI components were handled by Chakra UI, and the entire interface was designed in dark mode to give the system a modern look.
project-dragonfly-backend: For the backend, I chose the combination of Express.js and Prisma to implement a data API with strong typing and rapid development speed. For the authentication management API, I used Django REST Framework along with Django OAuth Toolkit to accelerate the deployment of a cutting-edge user authentication system.
project-dragonfly-mobile: Dragonfly GeoAnalytics also includes a mobile module, developed as a separate project.
project-dragonfly-contract: In this project, I was contracted by a Brazilian engineering company to develop all aspects related to the platform: the design, development, methodology for data collection, and cloud deployment.
project-dragonfly-deployment: Currently, the platform is deployed for various municipalities with a GitOps pipeline across the entire ecosystem, updating applications and infrastructure using the concept of Infrastructure as Code. All applications are containerized and deployed in Docker Swarm with Portainer.
project-geoserver-intro: The Geoserver Mobile Client is an application developed in Ionic, React, TypeScript, and OpenLayers that serves as a mobile client for Geoserver. The idea arose to meet the needs of users who already use a web system to manage geographic layers but required a mobile solution to download data, view it offline, access layers, edit features, and add new information directly from the device.
project-geoserver-dev: The choice of technologies, such as Ionic and React, was motivated by their flexibility and the vast ecosystem of mapping tools offered by OpenLayers, allowing for efficient rendering of vector and raster layers, as well as support for drawing complex features.
project-geoserver-frontend: The frontend was developed using Ionic and React, with OpenLayers for managing geographic data and rendering maps. The interfaces were built responsively, enabling intuitive and efficient navigation on mobile devices.
project-geoserver-backend: Geoserver was the only backend used in the project, leveraging its REST APIs to manage workspaces, stores, layers, users, and styles, eliminating the need for additional backend development.
project-geoserver-mobile: The app was developed for mobile devices with full support for offline interaction, allowing users to download data, access geographic layers, and edit features directly in the app.
project-geoserver-contract: This project was developed within the company I work for and took 3 weeks to complete, from requirements gathering to publishing the app on Google Play.
project-geoserver-deployment: The app was published via Ionic Appflow, with a non-listed distribution on Google Play, accessible only to authorized users by the client.
project-geoserver-description: This mobile client for Geoserver allows users to access geographic layers on their mobile device, supporting offline feature downloads, field data collection, and export in GeoJSON format.
skyforest-title: Automating Geospatial Data Processing and Delivery for Skyforest
skyforest-intro: Skyforest needed an efficient way to process and distribute large volumes of drone imagery and forestry data through GeoServer. The manual workflow required mosaicking images, generating pyramids, configuring GeoServer, managing users, and delivering credentials to clients.
skyforest-solution: To streamline this process, I developed an event-driven system in Node.js that automated the entire pipeline. A monitoring service, integrated with Redis, detected file changes by comparing hashes, ensuring only new or modified data was processed. GDAL pipelines handled compression and pyramid generation, optimizing files for web delivery. GeoServer configurations, including workspaces, stores, layers, and user permissions, were created dynamically. A queueing mechanism in Redis managed processing tasks efficiently, preventing memory overloads.
skyforest-interface: To enhance client experience, I built a web interface where users could log in, access their data, and retrieve documentation without needing technical support.
skyforest-impact: The system significantly reduced manual effort, improved performance by optimizing data processing, and scaled efficiently as data volumes grew. Skyforest's clients gained direct access to their datasets with minimal friction.
skyforest-conclusion: This project allowed me to bridge frontend and backend development, integrating GDAL pipelines, Redis-based automation, and GeoServer configuration into a seamless data delivery system.
skyforest-technologies: Technologies used: Node.js, Redis, GDAL, GeoServer, and a Linux-based geospatial server.
contact-text: I'm open to consulting opportunities and interesting projects. Feel free to reach out!
project-pointcloud-description: A full-fledged point cloud processing framework developed in n8n to publish data to Potree, optimizing speed, quality and resource usage. Developed as a backend service for a SaaS system.
project-pointcloud-intro: This framework was built to handle large-scale point cloud processing workflows, automating the entire pipeline from raw data ingestion to optimized Potree visualization. The system leverages n8n's workflow automation capabilities to orchestrate complex processing tasks including point cloud classification, compression, tiling, and metadata generation.
project-pointcloud-features: Key features include intelligent resource management to optimize processing speed and quality, dynamic queue management for handling multiple concurrent jobs, and seamless integration with Potree for web-based 3D visualization. The framework was designed as a backend service to support a SaaS platform, ensuring scalability and reliability for production environments.
project-pointcloud-technologies: Technologies used: n8n, Potree, GDAL, PDAL, Node.js, and cloud infrastructure.
project-territorial-description: A SaaS platform for publishing drone imagery directly from your computer into the system, streamlining the workflow from capture to publication.
project-territorial-intro: Territorial Maps simplifies the entire workflow of drone imagery management, from upload to publication. Users can directly upload imagery from their local machines, and the system handles all the complex processing including georeferencing, mosaicking, pyramid generation, and web-optimized tile creation.
project-territorial-features: The platform provides an intuitive interface for managing large volumes of aerial imagery, with automated processing pipelines that ensure optimal quality and performance. Built as a SaaS solution, it enables organizations to efficiently publish and share their drone-captured data without requiring extensive technical expertise or infrastructure management.
project-territorial-technologies: Technologies used: Next.js, React, Node.js, GDAL, GeoServer, and cloud infrastructure.
project-geo360-description: The first LADM compliant system in Brazil. I'm the lead engineer behind the conception and implementation of the system, working alongside engineers from Topocart.
project-geo360-intro: As the lead engineer, I was responsible for the architectural design and technical implementation of Brazil's first LADM (Land Administration Domain Model) compliant system. This project represents a significant milestone in Brazilian land administration, bringing international standards to the country's cadastral and land registry processes.
project-geo360-features: The system implements the ISO 19152 LADM standard, ensuring interoperability and compliance with international best practices for land administration. Working collaboratively with engineers from Topocart, we developed a comprehensive solution that handles complex land tenure relationships, rights, restrictions, and responsibilities (RRR) in a standardized, interoperable format.
project-geo360-impact: The implementation required deep understanding of both geospatial data modeling and land administration domain knowledge, combining technical expertise with regulatory compliance to create a system that serves as a reference for future land administration projects in Brazil.
project-geo360-technologies: Technologies used: PostgreSQL, PostGIS, GeoServer, React, Node.js, and LADM-compliant data models.
